At a meeting of the Athletic Association Board held
last Monday night, a motion

the managers of the various
athletic teams will be elected
by the teams. It was voted
that this provision should go
into effect at once. In the past,
all managers have been elected
by the board. This procedure
was hardly just, as the majority of the members of the
board knew little or nothing
as to the amount of work done
or the ability of the men in
question. Under the new
ruling, election will be in the
hands of those who are best
fitted to judge the respective
abilities of the candidates.

EDITORIALS
THE DECLINE OF STUDENT ACTIVITIES
HE number of recent appeals which the Barnstormers have made
for candidates for their annual show brings to the fore the question
of whether or not student activities at Hopkins are deteriorating. The
quality of student productions is not the question at issue since it varies
from activity to activity and from one production or issue of a publication to another. The question that is of importance to the campus is
the seemingly growing lack of interest in extra-curricular activities.
There are a number of manifestations at present that strongly support the impression that the members of the undergraduate body are
becoming less and less inclined to indulge in student affairs. The
Barnstormers case is one indication of this new spirit; the critical state
•of the Debating Council is another. However, other activities such as
the Black and Blue Jay and the Hullabaloo are not suffering from a
dearth of staff members and candidates.
Undoubtedly there is not as much discussion and argument on the
campus concerning activities as there was four years ago. Naturally
enough one is prone to believe that this lack of conversation on the
topic of student activities can only mean that a large majority of the
undergraduates find little interest in such matters. Therefore, even
considering some contradictory features, we believe that interest in
student activities has suffered a sharp decline in the last four years.
The fundamental reasons for this change in attitude are very difficult
to ascertain. The abolition of the freshman regulation that all yearlings
must try out for one activity has had some effect. But in the days
when that ruling was in force many freshmen merely signed up as a
candidate for one activity or another and never approached the office
again. So the abolition of this rule cannot be the sole cause of the
decline in interest. Many more men are going in for graduate work
since the New Plan was established than ever before and consequently
cannot afford the time to work on activities. While the two explanations offered above have had their effect, yet they do not tell the whole
story. Undergraduates today have experienced a change in their conception of relative values and the importance of being a "big man
on the campus" has dropped far down the scale. The reason remains
obscure; perhaps freshmen today are a little more intelligent than they
have been; perhaps a little more stupid. It all depends on your point
of view.

EDITORIALS
THE DECLINE OF STUDENT ACTIVITIES
HE number of recent appeals which the Barnstormers have made
for candidates for their annual show brings to the fore the question
of whether or not student activities at Hopkins are deteriorating. The
quality of student productions is not the question at issue since it varies
from activity to activity and from one production or issue of a publication to another. The question that is of importance to the campus is
the seemingly growing lack of interest in extra-curricular activities.
There are a number of manifestations at present that strongly support the impression that the members of the undergraduate body are
becoming less and less inclined to indulge in student affairs. The
Barnstormers case is one indication of this new spirit; the critical state
•of the Debating Council is another. However, other activities such as
the Black and Blue Jay and the Hullabaloo are not suffering from a
dearth of staff members and candidates.
Undoubtedly there is not as much discussion and argument on the
campus concerning activities as there was four years ago. Naturally
enough one is prone to believe that this lack of conversation on the
topic of student activities can only mean that a large majority of the
undergraduates find little interest in such matters. Therefore, even
considering some contradictory features, we believe that interest in
student activities has suffered a sharp decline in the last four years.
The fundamental reasons for this change in attitude are very difficult
to ascertain. The abolition of the freshman regulation that all yearlings
must try out for one activity has had some effect. But in the days
when that ruling was in force many freshmen merely signed up as a
candidate for one activity or another and never approached the office
again. So the abolition of this rule cannot be the sole cause of the
decline in interest. Many more men are going in for graduate work
since the New Plan was established than ever before and consequently
cannot afford the time to work on activities. While the two explanations offered above have had their effect, yet they do not tell the whole
story. Undergraduates today have experienced a change in their conception of relative values and the importance of being a "big man
on the campus" has dropped far down the scale. The reason remains
obscure; perhaps freshmen today are a little more intelligent than they
have been; perhaps a little more stupid. It all depends on your point
of view.

Conowingo, Maryland, is the
second largest hydro-electric development in the world. Power generated
there at 220,000 volts will be fed into
lower voltage transmission lines of the
Public Service Electric and Gas Company
at Roseland, near Newark, New Jersey.
The transformers that will perform
this transfer of energy are physically the
largest ever built, for their capacity is
sufficient to serve the home lighting
needs of a city of a million people.
Four in number, each is larger than a
house, weighs when empty as much as
a large locomotive and holds three

tank cars of oil. Four specially built
railway cars and fifty-two standard cars
of various types were required to transport them from the factory to the job.
At one point the railway tracks had to
be lowered so the units would clear an
overhead viaduct, so great was their size.
When spectacular jobs like this
come up, it is natural that they go to
an institution like Westinghouse. Pioneers in electrical development, Westinghouse engineers often know the
thrill of achieving the "impossible"
in seeing their work through
from design to erection.
